titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Marsden Hartley Collection
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday March 27, 2019 at 03:39

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection consists of writings, correspondence, photographs, and other materials documenting the personal and professional affairs of Modernist-era painter Marsden Hartley. Writings contain notes and drafts, autograph and typescript, for numerous writings, chiefly essays. Correspondence is spread out over the many groupings in the collection and features large files of outgoing letters to Norma Berger, Hartley's niece, Carl Sprinchorn, and Adelaide S. Kuntz, as well as incoming letters from artists, writers, cultural figures, and institutions. Correspondents include Hart Crane, Robert McAlmon, Henry Miller, Marianne Moore, Arnold Ronnebeck, Elizabeth Sparhawk-Jones, Gertrude Stein, Alfred Stieglitz, Carl Van Vechten, William Carlos Williams, and Edmund Wilson. There are also third-party letters between Berger and others concerning Hartley's work. Other materials include photographs, three oil paintings by Hartley, notebooks, and objects.

langmaterial.language: Chiefly in English; some materials in Spanish and German.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Acquired chiefly through gifts from Norma Berger, 1950-1978, with additional material from other sources, 1952-2005.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
37 (cold storage): Restricted fragile material. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Marsden Hartley Collection is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Marsden Hartley Collection. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and in some instances minimal organization upon acquisition. Further organization and description was carried out in 2012 on Hartley material received by the library between 1950 and 1978. In 2014-2015, other, chiefly later acquisitions of Hartley material were added to the collection. Descriptive information found in the Collection Contents section is drawn in large part from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically for revisions in arrangement and description.
Former call numbers: Za Hartley, Za Sprinchorn, Uncat Za File 28, Uncat Za Ms 67, Uncat Za Ms 75, and Uncat MSS 570.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Printed materials cataloged separately at Za H255 +1.

bioghist.head: Marsden Hartley (1877-1943)
bioghist.p: Marsden Hartley, an American modernist painter known for his depictions of the Maine coastline and fishermen, was born on 4 January 1877 in Lewiston Maine. After his family moved from Maine to Cleveland in 1892, Hartley studied art at the Cleveland School of Art (1893-1898), then the New York School of Art, and the National Academy of Design. Hartley moved to Berlin in 1913 and spent much of the next two decades in Europe before returning to the U.S. in 1930 and to Maine in 1937. Hartley died on 2 September 1943 in Ellsworth, Maine.
Biographical information taken from "Hartley, Marsden (1877-1943)." Encyclopedia of World Biography . Detroit: Gale, 1998. Gale Biography In Context . Web. 15 May 2012.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of writings, correspondence, photographs, and other materials documenting the personal and professional affairs of Modernist-era painter Marsden Hartley. Writings contain notes and drafts, autograph and typescript, for numerous writings, chiefly essays. Correspondence is spread out over the many groupings in the collection and features large files of outgoing letters to Norma Berger, Hartley's niece, Carl Sprinchorn, and Adelaide S. Kuntz, as well as incoming letters from artists, writers, cultural figures, and institutions. Correspondents include Hart Crane, Robert McAlmon, Henry Miller, Marianne Moore, Arnold Ronnebeck, Elizabeth Sparhawk-Jones, Gertrude Stein, Alfred Stieglitz, Carl Van Vechten, William Carlos Williams, and Edmund Wilson. There are also third-party letters between Berger and others concerning Hartley's work. Other materials include photographs, three oil paintings by Hartley, notebooks, and objects.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into fourteen groupings: 1950 Acquisition, Undated Acquisition, 1952-1953 Acquisitions, 1956-1976 Acquisitions, 1967 Acquisition, 1976 Acquisitions, 1978 Acquisition, Undated Acquisition, 1983 Acquisition, 1988 Acquisition, 1988 Acquisition, 1989 Acquisition, 2003 Acquisition, and 2005 Acquisition.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subgroupings: Writings, Letters to Norma Berger, and Other Materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Writings contain notes and drafts, autograph and typescript, for numerous writings, chiefly essays. The letters from Hartley to his niece, Norma Berger, span over four decades, dating from 1900 to 1943.
Former call number: Za Hartley.

did.unittitle: "Miscellaneous Papers Not Written by Marsden Hartley"
"Pamela the Bantam and Other Stories for Children"

"Twenty-five Essays European Topics / M. H.'s Handwriting"
"Be That As It May and Other Essays and Poems"
"Collections of Poems by Marsden Hartley Submitted to Dr. Henry W. Wells"
"Collections of Poems by Marsden Hartley Submitted to Dr. Henry W. Wells"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This group of material consists of letters to Hartley from others. Correspondents include artists, writers, cultural figures, and institutions, including Hart Crane, Robert McAlmon, Henry Miller, Marianne Moore, Arnold Ronnebeck, Elizabeth Sparhawk-Jones, Gertrude Stein, Alfred Stieglitz, Carl Van Vechten, William Carlos Williams, Edmund Wilson, and others. There are also a number of correspondents with ties to Hartley's home state of Maine.
Former call number: Za Hartley.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source unknown, but possibly Norma Berger.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes photographs

scopecontent.p: Includes photographs

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subgroupings: Correspondence, Writings, and Artwork.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This group of material consists of small acquisitions of letters from Hartley to others, one typescript carbon draft of "Digressions of a Cinemafano," and three oil paintings by Hartley.
Former call number: Za Hartley.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains photostats

did.unittitle: An Abstract Arrangement of American Indian Symbols
Collection of Numbers, Designs and Letters Seen by Me at the Beginning of the War in Berlin

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This grouping brings together several acquisitions consisting chiefly of correspondence. There are small groups of letters from Hartley to others as well as a large file of third-party correspondence between Hartley's niece, Norma Berger, and Carl Sprinchorn. Chiefly in English, with some material in German.
Former call number: Za Hartley.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Acquired from various sources, 1956-1976. Provenance traced on individual folders.

scopecontent.p: Includes third-party letters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes third-party lettters from Arnold Ronnebeck

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subgroupings: Letters to Carl Sprinchorn and Writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The 1967 Acquisition contains approximately 90 letters from Hartley to Carl Sprinchorn dating from 1932 to 1943, as well as a drafts to five short writings by Hartley.
Former call number: Za Sprinchorn.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subgroupings: Marsden Hartley Correspondence, Norma Berger Correspondence, Other Materials, and Writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains letters by Hartley and others and drafts for several essays.
Former call number: Za Hartley.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains typescript copies

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subgroupings: Correspondence and Other Materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence consists of third-party letters between Norma Berger and others concerning the work of Hartley. Correspondents include scholars, museums, and publishers. Other Materials include photographs and objects.
Dates attributed to folder contents listed below are circa dates.
Former call number: Za Hartley.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This group of material was temporarily mis-shelved during baseline processing of "Za Hartley" material in 2012.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source unknown, but possibly Norma Berger.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subgroupings: Photographs and Other Material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This group of material includes hundreds of photographs and other papers. The photographs include images of family members, Hartley, other people, places, and artwork by Hartley and others. Other papers consist chiefly of printed material, including clippings, ephemera, such as postcards, exhibition catalogs, and publicity, and magazines.
Former call number: Za Hartley.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Former call number: Uncat Za File 28.

did.unittitle: Transcriptions of letters to Hartley from Gertrude Stein, typescript, corrected

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The 1988 Acquisition features a lengthy correspondence from Hartley to Adelaide S. Kuntz dating from the mid 1920s through mid 1950s. Other materials include a photograph of Hartley and a card file containing an index of Hartley's letters to Kuntz by date and first line.
Former call number: Uncat Za Ms 67.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subgroupings: Correspondence and Photographs and Other Papers.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. John Kuntz, 1988.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Former call number: Uncat Za Ms 75.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subgroupings: Correspondence, Printed Material, and Photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The 2003 Acquisition consists of drafts, autograph manuscript, of short essays on artists and travel assembled by Hartley for a collection entitled "Varied Patterns".
Former call number: Uncat MSS 570.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Tony and Elspeth Vevers, 2003.
